conversation.content: I found the manifests, Tommy—the real ones, not the doctored versions you've been filing with customs for the past three years.
You shouldn't have come aboard, especially not in the middle of the night like this, not when we're twelve hours from international waters.
Twelve hours from what?
[quietly] From where corporate jurisdiction ends and maritime law begins, where your spreadsheets and quarterly reports mean absolutely nothing anymore.
[incredulous] You're actually threatening me? Your own sister? The one who covered for you when you flunked out of business school to chase this salt water fantasy?
[defensive] That fantasy built our father's empire into something real, something that actually moves through the world instead of just existing in portfolios and hedge funds.
[bitter laugh] Built it on what exactly? Because those containers marked 'agricultural equipment' sure as hell aren't carrying tractors, and we both know it.
[steadying himself] Sometimes keeping a company alive means navigating waters you never planned to enter—you'd understand that if you ever left your corner office.
Don't lecture me about survival when you're the one who's been systematically destroying everything Dad stood for, everything he believed this company could be.
[simmering] Dad's dead, Maria. [exhales] He's been dead for five years, and his principles died with him when the banks started circling like sharks.
[voice cracking] He trusted you with the fleet, trusted you to keep the family legacy clean, and this is what you've done with that faith?
[firmly] I kept us afloat when your brilliant financial strategies would have seen every ship impounded and every crew member on the breadline.
[desperately] There are other ways, Tommy—legal ways that don't involve smuggling God knows what for people who probably have blood on their hands.
Legal ways. [hollow laugh] Like the bankruptcy filing you've been secretly preparing? Yeah, I know about that too—we both have our secrets, apparently.
[pleading] That was a contingency plan, a last resort if we couldn't restructure the debt, but we still have options if you just stop this insanity.
Stop? [sighs]
[shakily] The authorities already know something's wrong—they've been asking questions about our routing patterns, about why we keep changing our navigation logs at the last minute.
[resigned] Then you'd better decide quickly whether you're going to turn in your own brother or help me navigate us through this storm we're both caught in now.
[whispered] How did we get here, Tommy? How did we go from Sunday dinners at Dad's house to me standing on your bridge, begging you not to destroy us?

[softly] We got here one compromise at a time, one impossible choice after another, until the only way forward was through waters neither of us wanted to sail. [pause] But we're still family, Maria—that has to count for something.

scenario: A CFO boards her brother's cargo ship after discovering their family's shipping company has been smuggling contraband alongside legitimate cargo for years.
